awd_titl_txt: Group Actions, Homogeneous Dynamics, and Number Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
Many questions in mathematics come with a set of symmetries that has a so-called group structure. Exploring the dynamics of underlying group actions, namely to study how points in spaces behave under symmetries, has recently played a central role in proving important results and resolving longstanding questions in mathematics. The overall aim of this research project is to advance the technique of using dynamics of group actions as a powerful tool to study questions that arise in algebra, geometry, and number theory, and to gain a deeper understanding of the connections between these mathematical fields.

In this project special attention will be given to the following three directions: (1) Develop reduction theory of indefinite integral quadratic forms and consider its generalization to number fields using methods of dynamical systems. (2) Investigate random walks on Lie groups and equidistribution problems in homogenous spaces in light of recent developments in spectral theory and the theory of automorphic forms.  (3) Study the height bounds of generators of arithmetic groups incorporating dynamical methods into classical algebraic and geometric theory of arithmetic groups. The project also aims to seek new interactions and develop the techniques in the study of groups, dynamics, and number theory.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project delved into the intriguing intersection of Lie groups theory, dynamics, and number theory, exploring the profound interplay among these distinct yet interconnected fields. The primary objective was to establish novel connections between various mathematical domains, particularly emphasizing the discrete and continuous aspects, and address a range of mathematical problems.


In collaboration with G. A. Margulis, the Principal Investigator (PI) advanced the existing knowledge by deriving new height bounds for the reduction of indefinite integral quadratic forms. These findings extended the methodologies grounded in the dynamics of Lie groups to study of the problems in number theory. The PI, alongside colleagues M. Aka, M. Einsiedler, and A. Mohammadi, obtained effective equidistribution results for arithmetic quotients of SL(d, R). Of note, these results eliminated the technical centralizer assumption, a substantial advancement from the previous work of Einsiedler-Margulis-Venkatesh (2007) within this specific context. Collaborating with W. K. Chan, the PI expanded upon his previous work with G. A. Margulis, extending the search bound of integral quadratic forms to encompass integral quadratic lattices over number fields. This extension incorporated methods and techniques from algebraic number theory, further integrating them into the dynamics of orthogonal groups. In a joint work with W. K. Chan and H. Gao, the PI achieved an effective version of Siegel's classical result regarding the equivalence of rational quadratic forms while avoiding prime numbers, while H. Gao worked as an undergraduate research advisee under the PI's supervision.


The PI has been serving as the PhD advisor to Jacob Tolman from Wesleyan University, contributing to the development of the next generation of mathematicians. The PI co-organized the "A Dynamical Weekend at Wesleyan" conference and facilitated the virtual "The New England Dynamics and Number Theory Seminar". Both events featured research talks covering ergodic theory, homogeneous dynamics, number theory, and their intersections. The PI co-founded and actively participated in "Little School Dynamics," a research community dedicated to supporting and promoting dynamics research at Primarily Undergraduate Institutions (PUIs). This initiative helps broaden access to and engagement in advanced mathematics research. The PI has continued to share research findings by participating in conferences, workshops, and presenting academic talks, disseminating the project's research findings to the broader mathematical community.
